docs.lead_paragraph: Viagra has become popular with gay men here and in other cities, reflecting a trend that has begun to worry health care experts, who fear that it may foster the spread of H.I.V. Many gay men, like many straight men, are using Viagra solely for its approved purpose -- as a remedy for persistent erectile dysfunction. Some H.I.V. positive gay men take it because the infection itself or the antiviral drugs may have reduced their abilities to perform sexually.

headline.main: Experts Fear a Risky Recipe: Viagra, Drugs and H.I.V.

docs.abstract: Viagra becomes popular with gay men in San Francisco and in other cities, reflecting a trend that has begun to worry health care experts, who fear that it may foster spread of HIV; many gay Viagra users are treating it like recrational drug and taking it along with Ecstasy and other illegal substances; some HIV educators now fear that this more casual use of Viagra could lead to unfortunate side effect: increase in unprotected anal intercourse; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Mark L. Rosenberg had always been proud to be a doctor. A former practicing physician and now the director of the Task Force for Child Survival and Development in Decatur, Ga., he followed his mother, a family practitioner, into medicine, graduating from Harvard Medical School in 1972. Polite, even courtly, he respected his colleagues and could never imagine disagreeing with another physician about the care of a patient. That was, however, until the patient was his own father.

headline.main: Doctors With Sick Parents See a System's Flaws

docs.abstract: Some doctors whose parents were ill observe first hand how inadequate medical care contributed to their parents' deaths; these doctors, over all, describe lack of responsiveness by health care providers, poor communication and confusion, loss of continuity of care and, most alarmingly, medical mistakes; study finds that some of patients whose children were doctors actually received 'suboptimal or even antagonistic care'; examples cited; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Dr. Mark L. Rosenberg had always been proud to be a doctor. A former practicing physician and now the director of the Task Force for Child Survival and Development in Decatur, Ga., he followed his mother, a family practitioner, into medicine,...

docs.lead_paragraph: With her 7-week-old baby nursing at her breast, Dr. Sandra Steingraber spoke at a conference held recently in New York to address an important issue: the presence of low levels of chemical residues in breast milk. Dr. Steingraber, an ecologist and a visiting assistant professor at Cornell University's program on breast cancer and environmental risk factors, described breast-feeding as ''a very exquisite communion between myself and my child'' -- but also a transfer of chemicals.

headline.main: Research Is Urged for Healthier Breast Milk

docs.abstract: Research is urged for healthier breast milk, in light of new concerns about chemicals in milk that may be transmitted to babies (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A popular type of antidepressant may help to reduce heart attack risk, researchers reported yesterday. Drugs like Prozac and Zoloft, known as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, or S.S.R.I.'s, may help prevent heart attacks by reducing blood clots, the researchers wrote in the journal Circulation.

headline.main: Gains for the Head and the Heart

docs.abstract: Researchers report that popular type of antidepressant may help to reduce heart attack risk; say drugs like Prozac and Zoloft, known as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, may help prevent heart attacks (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Preschool children whose mothers are obese or depressed tend to watch more television than other children, a study has found. The researchers, who presented their findings last week in Quebec at a conference of the North American Association for the Study of Obesity, said that in families they had studied, the children of obese mothers watched television on average half an hour more a day than the children over all, who watched for two hours a day. If the mothers were also depressed, the children watched about an hour more.

headline.main: In TV Habits, Like Mother, Like Child

docs.abstract: Study finds that preschool children whose mothers are obese or depressed tend to watch more television than other children (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Fifteen years ago, chronic headaches and an astute internist saved Chris Ihde's life. Mr. Ihde was 26, and an avid runner and long-distance cyclist. The doctor took a hard look at his patient -- 6 feet 4 inches tall, long-legged, long-armed and loose-jointed with a crooked chest bone, very long fingers and large narrow feet -- and said, ''You look like you have Marfan syndrome.''

headline.main: The Lifeline With Marfan's: Its Diagnosis

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column profiles Marfan syndrome, caused by mutant gene, that afflicts one in 5,000 to one in 10,000 people; Marfan's is highly variable but potentially deadly disorder of connective tissue involving defect in protein called fibrillin; people with Marfan's tend to be tall, thin, long-armed, loose-jointed and nearsighted; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When the authorities worry that our nation's public health system may be ill prepared to cope with a large-scale bioterrorist attack, they are talking about more than shortages of drugs, bandages and fax machines. They are also talking about some very bad habits that have crept into medical practice in the last few decades, leaving many doctors blithely out of touch with the details of the world of the germs. Take the case of my patient Ruth. She had nothing much to report on the phone last week: fever and a cough. She and her small son are constantly getting chest infections. Usually she gets an antibiotic and gets better. This time she had gotten two different antibiotics, one after another, during two different visits to our clinic while I was on vacation, and she was still sick.

headline.main: Relearning Lost Skills For New Era

docs.lead_paragraph: A California plastic surgeon says he has developed a way to reduce the pain caused by injections: freezing the needles first. The technique, described in a recent Journal of the American Medical Association, could be welcome news to any parent taking a child to a doctor, to say nothing of diabetics who require regular injections.

headline.main: A Needle on Ice to Ease the Pain

docs.abstract: California plastic surgeon Dr Keith Denkler says he has developed way to reduce pain caused by injections: freezing needles first (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The American Heart Association has issued a warning against high-protein diets, saying they do not promote long-term weight loss and may even pose a risk to cardiovascular health. The advisory appeared in a recent issue of Circulation, a heart association journal, and prompted a quick denunciation from proponents of the Atkins diet, a popular high-protein plan. The heart association, the Atkins group said, ''seems to have sidelined state-of-the-heart science and has done nothing but further confuse the American public.'' The lead author of the heart association's advisory, Dr. Robert H. Eckel, a past chairman of the group's nutrition committee, noted the appeal this type of diet holds for many people and said, ''I think the American Heart Association felt that it was time to provide some sort of statement.'' More than half of all Americans are overweight, and many turn to high-protein diets because they can produce a quick initial weigh loss. The heart association warned that the loss is only temporary. ''If short-term is all you get the benefit for, then is it worth doing?'' Dr. Eckel asked. The advisory also said that while these diets might not harm most healthy people for a short period, they could be troublesome long term. The diet relies heavily on meat, eggs and dairy products, the article said, raising people's exposure to fat and cholesterol.
docs.abstract: American Heart Association issues warning against high-protein diets, saying they do not promote long-term weight loss and may even pose a risk to cardiovascular health (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Athletes who drink so-called superoxygenated water because they think it will help their performance are wasting their money, a new report says. Writing in Fitness Matters, a publication of the American Council on Exercise, researchers said the products showed no benefits over regular water.

headline.main: When Athletes Drink Souped Up Water

docs.abstract: New report finds that athletes who drink so-called superoxygenated water because they think it will help their performance are wasting their money (S)
